rogel.io.fopl.terms

Class Term

  • java.lang.Object
    • rogel.io.fopl.terms.Term
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Expression, Unifiable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Function, Variable

    public abstract class Term
extends java.lang.Object
implements Unifiable
    Terms name objects or things. As such, Terms require at least one Symbol, to uniquely identify the Term within the domain of discourse.
    Author:
    recardona

    • Method Detail

      • getSymbol

        public final Symbol getSymbol()
        Gets the Symbol associated with this Term.
        Returns:
        the Symbol.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Compares this Term to the parameter object. The result is true if and only if the argument is another Term with the same symbol.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        obj - The object to compare this Symbol against.
        Returns:
        true if the given object represents a Term with the same Symbol as this Term, false otherwise.

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a hash code for this Term. The hash code for a Term object is computed as the hash of the underlying Symbol that represents this term; i.e. getSymbol().hashCode()
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representation of this Term. Since this class is abstract, the class defers to the toString() methods of the known implementing classes: Function and Variable.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a String representation of this object.

      • containsVariable

        public static boolean containsVariable(java.util.List<Term> terms,
                       Variable variable,
                       Substitution substitution)
        Checks to see if the parameter List of Terms contains the parameter Variable, given an existing set of Substitutions (which may involve the Variable to check for). This method accomplishes what is colloquially referred to as the "occurs check" during unification.

        This method is used by two types of Unifiable Objects which have access to a List of Unifiable Terms: Predicates and Functions.

        Parameters:
        terms - A List of Terms to check through, not null.
        variable - The Variable to check for, not null.
        substitution - The existing set of Substitutions to work with, not null.
        Returns:
        true if any of the Terms in the List contains the Variable, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Predicate.containsVariable(Variable, Substitution), Function.containsVariable(Variable, Substitution)
